summary: No spoilers, but Avengers: Endgame was the campiest, funniest MCU movie I’ve ever seen. Clocking in at three hours, they managed...
body: No spoilers, but Avengers: Endgame was the campiest, funniest MCU movie I’ve ever seen. Clocking in at three hours, they managed to include all the moments that were made to fan over, while pacing the large, yet meticulous plot well. Despite this installment’s sheer emotionality (a great achievement for Marvel), I spent a quarter of the movie laughing at them and another laughing with them, because they just had so much fun making it. The mourning, endurance and hope of Endgame is all the more fitting, because in totality, it’s a well-executed sendoff to the first decade of MCU and the cast that made it happen.

Despite this installment’s sheer emotionality (a great achievement for Marvel), I spent a quarter of the movie laughing at them and another laughing with them, because they just had so much fun making it. The mourning, endurance and hope of Endgame is all the more fitting, because in totality, it’s a well-executed sendoff to the first decade of MCU and the cast that made it happen.

Also cartoons, toys, anime and whatever else catches my eye.

Basic rule - Don't be a dick... unless you can be Dick Grayson, in which case be Dick Grayson because, paradoxically, he wouldn't be a dick,

blog.name: blackwidows-backup
blog.title: Marvel Obsessed
blog.description: I'm obsessed with all things Marvel.

summary: Heroes Are Not Angels, and Villains Are Not Demons
body:
Heroes Are Not Angels, and Villains Are Not Demons

Alright, so there’s this whole thing going around about the Captain Marvel deleted scene, and some are calling her a villain rather than her proclaimed title of a hero.

Personally, I think that entire claim is absurd. Would you like to know why? I have a list.

  • Peggy Carter punched a man for being degrading towards women
  • Darcy Lewis tased Thor because he was a little frightening and mildly crazy
  • Tony Stark was a womanizer
  • Steve Rogers is a war criminal and frankly a hypocrite
  • Clint Barton is a murderer, you can’t reframe that; he just is
  • Natasha Romanoff worked for the KGB
  • Bruce Banner has hurt people in his Hulk form, against his will
  • Thor was arrogant and annoying; he only cared about himself
  • Wanda and Pietro Maximoff voluntarily worked for HYDRA
  • James Rhodes stole a suit from Tony and passed it to Tony’s enemies
  • Bucky Barnes is wanted in nearly every country for his crimes
  • Sam Wilson is a war criminal that puts loyalty above accountability
  • Scott Lang has committed multiple felonies and stole the Ant-Man suit
  • Peter Parker caused much destruction to his city with his interferences
  • Stephen Strange was an egotistical narcissist intent on being the best
  • Peter Quill stole for money
  • Gamora killed for fun and for profit
  • Drax killed for both enjoyment and revenge
  • Rocket and Groot were con-artists and thieves
  • Mantis worked for Ego, despite knowing his true intentions
  • Yondu is a known kidnapper
  • Valkyrie betrayed her realm and kidnapped her king
  • Heimdall betrayed his king and became an enemy of the state
  • Okoye, Shuri, and Nakia betrayed their country to fight for the throne
  • Erik (killmonger) murdered his teammates and his lover
  • Howard Stark was neglectful and emotionally abusive
  • Vision, though accidental, shot down and paralyzed Rhodes
  • The Ancient One defied the rules and used dark magic
  • Hela killed her own people for the throne
  • Odin imprisoned Hela and lied to Loki about his parentage
  • Loki attempted to kill the people of Earth and take the Asgardian throne
  • Nebula served Thanos and tried to kill the guardians on multiple occasions
  • The comics version of Hank Pym was abusive towards his girlfriend
  • The Grandmaster forced people to kill each other for entertainment
  • Ronan and Ultron each tried to destroy a planet and annhilate a race
  • Thanos attempted and succeeded at killing half of life in the universe

But Carol Danvers is a villain? Excuse me?

I love almost all of these characters from the bottom of my heart, truly. But it’s no secret that they’ve all made grave and frankly, idiotic mistakes.

Just because they are our heroes does not mean that they are righteous. They are not angels.

And the same policy goes for antagonists. Just because they are villains does not mean they have evil intentions. They are not demons.

I’m just going to leave this here and let people see it. And maybe realize that a woman standing up for herself, while perhaps going a bit too far, is not villainous.

blog.name: apensivelady
blog.title: A Pensive Lady
blog.description: Trying to make sense of the world.

summary: A personal opinion on Steve Rogers’s ending in Avengers: Endgame
body:
A personal opinion on Steve Rogers’s ending in Avengers: Endgame

Seeing all the discussions about Steve Rogers’s ending in Endgame made me realise that the big issue with it is the fact that we don’t know anything about what actually happened to him.

The rules set by the movie regarding time travel are completely flawed. There’s the whole you-can’t-change-the-past’s-future-because-your-visit-to-the-past-is-your-future, but you also have the changes-in-the-past-alter-the-past’s-timeline. So, does this mean that the past is one timeline and the present is another? Because, to my understanding, they are the same timeline, since one is going back to one’s own timeline. The timeline that someone visits is one’s own, therefore a change in the past creates a new timeline and, consequently, doesn’t allow for what is the present to exist. The movie isn’t dealing with different universes, but with one same universe, thus, with one same timeline.

So, if one alters the past one is altering the future of the past, and, consequently, what was one’s present. This is theoretically corroborated by the fact that the stones have to be returned to the exact moment and place where they were taken from, otherwise there will be a break in the timeline of the past. A break that creates a new timeline, which means a different sequence of events for that universe. Therefore, if you visit the past and alter it in any way, you alter the timeline and its future. So, as you can see, Markus and McFeely didn’t really think through their time travel mechanics.

If the stones have to be returned so that the past is kept intact, as well as the timeline, Steve’s decision to remain in the past, in order to have no impact in the present time, would mean that he didn’t alter anything in the past. Which would mean that he would have let past atrocities just happen, otherwise he would incur in changing the timeline. Not only that, but if he did go back in time and actually married Peggy, like it’s hinted that he did, he erased the existence of her children with the husband she actually had in the original timeline. And both things are absolutely appalling and completely out of character for Steve Rogers. Other than that, this would mean that Steve actually changed the timeline, so we have a problem in how the present in the movie remained the same.

Now, if we are to believe that alterations in the past create parallel timelines to the ones that brought about the present of the movie, which, in my opinion, isn’t coherent to the idea of a timeline, we don’t know what Steve has done, how he acted in that timeline. All we can do is suppose that, even though he built a family, he remained the same guy, he had the same character, and acted to make the world better while being a family man. However, this doesn’t explain how he appeared as an old man in the other timeline that supposedly remained in existence unaltered.

The Russos said that Steve created a different timeline when he went to the past and stayed there, hinting at the existence of parallel timelines, but they didn’t tell us what happens in that timeline, nor how senior Steve goes back to the other timeline.

Differently, Markus and McFeely said that Steve didn’t change the timeline, that he was the very husband that Peggy talked about in Captain America: the Winter Soldier and that he was the father of her children all along. This would mean that Steve would have knowledge of the things that would come to pass, and that he would have consciously decided to stay out of them in order that the timeline were kept intact.

The fact is that the closure of Steve’s arc wasn’t thought through, at all. So we don’t actually know what happened to him. Steve had to go because Chris Evans was leaving the MCU, but he was given the worst possible ending. An ending that has nothing to do with who Steve Rogers had been throughout the MCU. I don’t have a problem with Steve retiring from “active duty”. Steve wouldn’t be selfish for doing that. What I have a problem with is the manner in which Steve was retired in Endgame. It didn’t take into consideration his whole character development in the MCU, which curiously was mainly written by Markus and McFeely themselves, and it left room for the interpretation that Steve chose to retire in a past he had full knowledge of, of how it would unfold, and that he consciously chose to live in it knowing he couldn’t alter it. And this is what hurt me. That my favourite Marvel character was turned into something he could never be. So when I see people saying that if I believe this is what Steve did, then I do not know him, I can only answer by saying that the movie was constructed in a way that one can conclude that. And this is why my heart was broken. Because the Steve that I know was turned into a Steve that I do not know. Because the Steve that I know couldn’t sit while so many atrocities unfolded all around him. I can’t possibly believe that he could just retire and live a suburban life knowing very well all the bad things that were bound to happen. This isn’t Steve Rogers. Steve Rogers wouldn’t sit on the sidelines while Hydra was sure to rise and his best friend was sure to be abused and tortured by it.

Markus and McFeely, the Russos and everyone else that green lit this ending for Steve Rogers managed to turn him into something he could never be in just a couple of minutes. Because they couldn’t conceive a manner of Steve retiring in the present. I wrote an option some time ago, but I’m sure there could have been many other ways of doing it. Steve didn’t deserve an ending that leaves open the interpretation of him becoming everything he could never be.

reblog.comment:
A personal opinion on Steve Rogers’s ending in Avengers: Endgame

Seeing all the discussions about Steve Rogers’s ending in Endgame made me realise that the big issue with it is the fact that we don’t know anything about what actually happened to him.

The rules set by the movie regarding time travel are completely flawed. There’s the whole you-can’t-change-the-past’s-future-because-your-visit-to-the-past-is-your-future, but you also have the changes-in-the-past-alter-the-past’s-timeline. So, does this mean that the past is one timeline and the present is another? Because, to my understanding, they are the same timeline, since one is going back to one’s own timeline. The timeline that someone visits is one’s own, therefore a change in the past creates a new timeline and, consequently, doesn’t allow for what is the present to exist. The movie isn’t dealing with different universes, but with one same universe, thus, with one same timeline.

So, if one alters the past one is altering the future of the past, and, consequently, what was one’s present. This is theoretically corroborated by the fact that the stones have to be returned to the exact moment and place where they were taken from, otherwise there will be a break in the timeline of the past. A break that creates a new timeline, which means a different sequence of events for that universe. Therefore, if you visit the past and alter it in any way, you alter the timeline and its future. So, as you can see, Markus and McFeely didn’t really think through their time travel mechanics.

If the stones have to be returned so that the past is kept intact, as well as the timeline, Steve’s decision to remain in the past, in order to have no impact in the present time, would mean that he didn’t alter anything in the past. Which would mean that he would have let past atrocities just happen, otherwise he would incur in changing the timeline. Not only that, but if he did go back in time and actually married Peggy, like it’s hinted that he did, he erased the existence of her children with the husband she actually had in the original timeline. And both things are absolutely appalling and completely out of character for Steve Rogers. Now, if we are to believe that alterations in the past create parallel timelines to the ones that brought about the present of the movie, which, in my opinion, isn’t coherent to the idea of a timeline, we don’t know what Steve has done, how he acted in that timeline. All we can do is suppose that, even though he built a family, he remained the same guy, he had the same character, and acted to make the world better while being a family man. However, this doesn’t explain how he appeared as an old man in the other timeline that supposedly remained in existence unaltered.

Steve Rogers wouldn’t sit on the sidelines while Hydra was sure to rise and his best friend was sure to be abused and tortured by it.

Steve didn’t deserve an ending that leaves open the interpretation of him becoming everything he could never be.

blog.name: lookitschynna
blog.title: I Have No Idea What I’m Doing
blog.description:
Chynna/Chy. 20-something bi MidWesterner (read as: Ohioan). This blog is a hot fucking mess. There’s like, social justice, fandom shit, and mental breakdowns. It’s crazy. And occasionally NSFW. I write over on @chynnawrites.

Icon by lesbuchanan

tags: i love him so much and i want to hug him a lot okay?
summary: Just cried for 10 minutes while trying to fall asleep because I was thinking about Thor in Endgame and how much I love him and...
body: Just cried for 10 minutes while trying to fall asleep because I was thinking about Thor in Endgame and how much I love him and how much he’s been through.
